---

This following is a brief summary of our research meetings on 2025-08-20.

## Meeting summary
---

We first talked about the notion of submodules in the category $F[G]\textbf{-Mod}$ and then showed how the notion translated to the equivalent categories  $\textbf{Vec}_F^{\textbf{G}}$ and $F\textbf{-Lin}_G$^[I can't remember if this is the notation we settled on for $F$-linear representations.] There were no surprises, fortunately.

When then talked about the general notion of *subobjects* in categories. We saw that some categories, like ${\bf Set}$ have a special object $\Omega$ called a **subobject classifier** (equipped with an arrow from the terminal object of the category) such that arrows to the subobject classifier are in natural bijection with subobjects. We went through the example of ${\bf Set}$, in which $\Omega=\{0,1\}$, the terminal object is $\{1\}$, the map $\text{true}:\{1\}\to \Omega$ is the set map that sends $1\mapsto 1$, and how for each set $X$ and subset $S\subseteq X$, there is a unique map $f:X\to \Omega$ such that the inclusion $S\hookrightarrow X$ is the pullback of the "truth" map $t:\{1\}\to \Omega$:

rotate(0 12.513992168768524 4.315169713368448)"><use href="#image-c0cbf4a5b7736dc25f3aa923ee9eb2e9a1ea57f0" width="25" height="9" opacity="1"/></g></svg>

This sounds fancy, but the map $f:X\to \Omega$ is simply the map

$$f(x)=\begin{cases}0,&\text{if }x\not\in S\\1,&\text{if }x\in S\end{cases}$$

Then we wondered whether most categories had subobject classifiers, and I quick search of the internet (mainly nLab) told us the answer: no. In particular, categories like ${\bf Grp}$ and ${\bf Vec}_F$ do not have subobject classifiers.

Without such a classifier, the fallback is to viewing subobjects as "equivalence classes of monics".

For us, the takeway is that we will probably have a hard time extending the notions of "submodules" and "direct sums" to the landscape of $C$-valued representations of a group $G$, i.e., to categories like $C^{\bf G}$. So for now we'll stick to representations with values in ${\bf Set}$, ${\bf Vec}_F$ and ${\bf Top}$.


## Tasks for next meeting
---

- Investigate the notions of subobjects in the familiar categories ${\bf Set}$, ${\bf Vec}_F$ and ${\bf Top}$, and then extend the notions of *reducible* and *irreducible* representations to these new settings,
- Recall the definition of the [[40-49 Knowledge/41 Mathematics/Category theory/Abelian categories/Preadditive categories#Biproducts\|biproduct]] in a preadditive category, and also scan the general info about the notion of *direct sum* over at [Wikipedia](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Direct_sum). Then try to extend the notions of *decomposable* and *indecomposable* to ${\bf Vec}_F$ and ${\bf Top}$. What goes wrong with ${\bf Set}$?
